name: wing
content:
wing

noun
 
 
/wɪŋ/
 
/wɪŋ/
Idioms
jump to other results

    of bird/insect

  1. enlarge image
     
     [countable] one of the parts of the body of a bird, insect or bat that it uses for flying
    • The swan flapped its wings noisily.
    • wing feathers
    Extra Examples
    • I wish I could sprout wings and fly away.
    • It flapped its wings and flew off.
    • It had white markings on its wings.
    • The beetle's fore wings are small and are not used in flight.
    • The young birds were under the mother bird's wing.
    • a bird with a broken wing
    • the patterns on butterfly wings
    Topics Birdsb1
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • left
    • right
    • front
    • …
    … of wings
    • pair
    verb + wing
    • extend
    • flex
    • open
    • …
    wing + verb
    • beat
    • flap
    • flutter
    • …
    wing + noun
    • tip
    • feathers
    • span
    • …
    preposition
    • on a/​the wing
    • under a/​the wing
    See full entry
  2.  
     the wing of a chicken, etc. eaten as food
    • We ordered the fried chicken wings.
    • First, fry the chicken wings in the oil until they begin to brown.
    see also Buffalo wingsTopics Foodb1

    3. of plane

  3. enlarge image
     
     [countable] one of the large flat parts that stick out from the side of a plane and help to keep it in the air when it is flying
    • Salvage teams have been able to recover part of the wing of the plane.
    • The right wing grazed the runway on landing.
    Topics Transport by airb1
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • aircraft
    • left
    • port
    • …
    wing + noun
    • tip
    See full entry
    4.

    of building

  4. [countable] a part of a large building that sticks out from the main part
    • the east wing
    • the new wing of the hospital
    • Our rooms were in the west wing.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • north
    • south
    • etc.
    • …
    verb + wing
    • add
    • build
    preposition
    • in a/​the wing
    See full entry
    5.

    of car

  5. enlarge image
    (British English)
    (North American English fender)
    [countable] a part of a car that is above a wheel
    • There was a dent in the nearside wing.
    Extra Examples
    • There was a dent in one wing.
    • The nearside wing was damaged in the accident.
    Topics Transport by car or lorryc2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • nearside
    • offside
    • front
    • …
    verb + wing
    • damage
    • dent
    • mend
    • …
    wing + noun
    • mirror
    preposition
    • in a/​the wing
    See full entry
    6.

    of organization

  6. [countable] one section of an organization that has a particular function or whose members share the same opinions synonym arm
    • The radical wing of the party was dissatisfied with the policies.
    • The political wing of the National Resistance Army entered into negotiations with the government.
    • They're on the left wing of the Labour Party.
    see also left wing, right wingTopics Politicsc1
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • left
    • right
    • conservative
    • …
    preposition
    • on a/​the wing
    See full entry
    7.

    in football/hockey

  7. (also winger)
     [countable] (sport) either of the attacking players who play towards the side of the playing area in sports such as football (soccer) or hockey see also left wing, right wing
  8. [countable] the far left or right side of the sports field
    • He plays on the wing.
    Extra Examples
    • He was playing on the right wing.
    • The ball went down the right wing.
    Topics Sports: ball and racket sportsc2

    9. in theatre

  9. the wings
     [plural] the area at either side of the stage that cannot be seen by the audience
    • She watched every performance from the wings.
    Wordfinder
    • backdrop
    • costume
    • curtain
    • footlights
    • prop
    • proscenium
    • scenery
    • set
    • stage
    • the wings
    Extra Examples
    • We watched from the wings.
    • She was waiting in the wings, ready to go on stage when her turn came.
    Topics Film and theatrec2
    10. Word OriginMiddle English (originally in the plural): from Old Norse vængir, plural of vængr.
Idioms
clip somebody’s wings
  1. to limit a person’s freedom or power
    • Having a new baby to take care of has clipped her wings.
get your wings
  1. to pass the exams that mean you are allowed to fly a plane
(waiting) in the wings
  1. ready to take over a particular job or be used in a particular situation when needed
    • She was aware of a whole host of ambitious young managers waiting in the wings.
    • There's a wealth of talent waiting in the wings of British theatre.
on the wing
  1. (literary) (of a bird, insect, etc.) flying
on a wing and a prayer
  1. with only a very slight chance of successTopics Successc2
spread your wings
  1. to become more independent and confident and try new activities, etc.
    • Going to college gave her the chance to spread her wings.
take somebody under your wing
  1. to take care of and help somebody who has less experience of something than you
    • Simon's uncle had taken him under his wing.
take wing
  1. (literary) (of a bird, insect, etc.) to fly away
    • (figurative) Her imagination took wing.
See wing in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee wing in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: wing
relatives: on a wing and a prayer

name: wing
content:
wing

verb
 
/wɪŋ/
 
/wɪŋ/
Verb Forms
present simple I / you / we / they wing
 
/wɪŋ/
 
/wɪŋ/
he / she / it wings
 
/wɪŋz/
 
/wɪŋz/
past simple winged
 
/wɪŋd/
 
/wɪŋd/
past participle winged
 
/wɪŋd/
 
/wɪŋd/
-ing form winging
 
/ˈwɪŋɪŋ/
 
/ˈwɪŋɪŋ/
Idioms
jump to other results

    fly

  1. [transitive, intransitive] wing (its way) + adv./prep. (literary) to fly somewhere
    • A solitary seagull winged its way across the bay.
    • He spotted the occasional pheasant winging rapidly away as he approached.
    2.

    go quickly

  2. [transitive] wing its way + adv./prep. to be sent somewhere very quickly
    • An application form will be winging its way to you soon.
    3. Word OriginMiddle English (originally in the plural): from Old Norse vængir, plural of vængr.
Idioms
wing it
  1. (informal) to do something without planning or preparing it first synonym improvise
    • I didn't know I'd have to make a speech—I just had to wing it.
See wing in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: wing
relatives: on a wing and a prayer

name: fender
content:
fender

noun
 
/ˈfendə(r)/
 
/ˈfendər/
jump to other results
  1. enlarge image
    (North American English)
    (British English wing)
    a part of a car that is above a wheelTopics Transport by car or lorryc2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • front
    • rear
    verb + fender
    • dent
    fender + noun
    • bender
    See full entry
  2. (North American English)
    (British English mudguard)
    a curved cover over a wheel of a bicycle or motorcycle
  3. a frame around a fireplace to prevent burning coal or wood from falling out
  4. a soft solid object such as an old tyre or a piece of rope that is hung over the side of a boat so the boat is not damaged if it touches another boat, a wall, etc.
See fender in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

name: left wing
content:
left wing

noun
 
/ˌleft ˈwɪŋ/
 
/ˌleft ˈwɪŋ/
jump to other results
  1. [singular + singular or plural verb] the part of a political party whose members are most in favour of social change
    • on the left wing of the party
    Topics Politicsc1
  2. [countable, uncountable] an attacking player or position on the left side of the field in a sports game
See left wing in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

name: The West Wing
content:
The West Wing

 
/ðə ˈwest wɪŋ/
 
/ðə ˈwest wɪŋ/
jump to other results
  1. a popular US television drama series on NBC which was shown from 1999 until 2006 about a US President, played by Martin Sheen, and his staff. It often dealt with current political issues and won a number of Emmys.
Check pronunciation: The West Wing
